lesson_objectives: • In this lesson, you'll see a demo of MovieQuotes, the app that we'll write together in this unit.
• In this lesson, you'll learn why Firebase is nice to use as a backend for mobile clients.

• In this lesson, you'll create a Firebase account and do some setup for the backend of the MovieQuotes app we'll write. This will include importing some starting quotes and setting up rules to access the data. You'll also use the Firebase Forge to manipulate the data.
• In this optional lesson, you'll learn how to install a pre-existing web client so you'll be able to see real time changes between multiple clients.
• In this lesson, you will download the code for the MovieQuotes app and set up the project to use Firebase.
• In this lesson, you will learn about Firebase's JSON data model and how to push data to Firebase.
• In this lesson, you'll learn about ChildEventListeners and data snapshots.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to delete items from the Firebase and how to listen for deletions, whether made locally or from other clients.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to push updates to the Firebase.

• The lab specification is here.
  • If you are taking this course in the academic year, get your lab checked off by an instructor or assistant. If you are taking it in the summer, submit your zipped project plus video demo and complete the Moodle 'Firebase' self-evaluation survey before calling it a day.
• In this lesson, you'll get an introduction to the PasswordKeeper app that we'll create in this unit. It has options to authenticate using email&password, Google, and Rose-Hulman credentials.
• In this lesson, you'll download the starting code and get an introduction to the parts that we will need to modify.
• In this lesson, you will learn about how to restrict and validate access to various paths in your Firebase.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to set up users in Firebase to use email&password authentication.
• In this lesson, you'll write code to check if a user is authenticated, to authenticate them, and to respond once Firebase passes back an authentication token.
• In this lesson, you'll do all the setup required to authenticate vs Google using OAuth.

• In this lesson, you'll write the code to authenticate a user using their google account. It's more complex than email&password, since we must handle google sign-in and get an OAuth token from Google.
• In this lesson, we'll get a registry token from the Rosefire server that we need in our app.
• In this lesson, we'll write 3 lines of code to authenticate using Rosefire. Really.

• The lab specification is here.
  • If you are taking this course in the academic year, get your lab checked off by an instructor or assistant. If you are taking it in the summer, submit your zipped project plus video demo and complete the Moodle 'FirebaseAuth' self-evaluation survey before calling it a day.
• In this lesson, you'll get an introduction to the GradeRecorder app that we'll invistigate and extend in this unit.
• In this lesson, we'll design the data models for the GradeRecorder app.
• In this lesson, you'll download the starting code and get a quick introduction to the parts that we will need to modify.
• In this lesson, you'll investigate the Student and Assignment fragments and adapters and learn about Queries and SingleValueEvents.
• In this lesson, you'll investigate the Course and Owner fragments and adapters to see an example of doubly-linked data and cascaded listeners.

• The lab specification is here.
  • If you are taking this course in the academic year, get your lab checked off by an instructor or assistant. If you are taking it in the summer, submit your zipped project plus video demo and complete the Moodle 'FirebaseComplexData' self-evaluation survey before calling it a day.
